contentHtml:
Koko Eating Bananas

You have an array pilespilespiles representing the bananas in a pile and an integer hhh representing hours. You must return a value kkk of how many bananas you can eat per pile that totals less than hhh.

The goal is to minimize the amount of bananas per pile, so reduce kkk to its smallest value.

Example:

  • piles=[2,4,5,7]piles = [2, 4, 5, 7]piles=[2,4,5,7]
  • h=8h = 8h=8
    • Output:3Output: 3Output:3
      • (2/3)=1(2/3) = 1(2/3)=1
      • (4/3)=2(4/3) = 2(4/3)=2
      • (5/3)=2(5/3) = 2(5/3)=2
      • (7/3)=3(7/3) = 3(7/3)=3
      • Total=8Total = 8Total=8

How to Solve?

The easiest way to solve how many bananas you must eat is to simply look at the largest value in the array.

  • 777.

If I eat 777 bananas per hours, it takes me 444 hours to finish all the bananas. This is going to be our upper bound. Quite simply, we can iterate from eating 111 banana to 777 bananas and find the minimum to eat all of them in 888 hours or less.

Binary Search

But why do that? Now that we know our lower bound is 111 and our upper bound is 777, is there an algorithm we can utilize to reduce our runtime?

Yes there is, and the approach is very intuitive. Our lower bound is our left pointer lll, and our upper bound is our right pointer rrr.

  • We can use binary search.

Below, I will simulate how binary search is going to work. We will use a middle pointer kkk to get the middle index between lll and rrr. We are going to halve our possibilities each iteration.

  • piles=[2,4,5,7]piles = [2, 4, 5, 7]piles=[2,4,5,7]
  • h=8h = 8h=8
  • l=1l = 1l=1
    • Minimum of 111 banana.
  • r=7r = 7r=7
    • r=max(piles)r = max(piles)r=max(piles)
  • res=rres = rres=r
    • Our worst case is to return the maximum amount of hours.
  • hours=0hours = 0hours=0

Utilize the formula:

  • k=l+((r−l)//2)k = l + ((r - l) // 2)k=l+((r−l)//2)
    • For getting the middle index
l r k

  • k=4k = 4k=4
    • (l+r)//2=4(l + r) // 2 = 4(l+r)//2=4
  • hours=6hours = 6hours=6
    • hours+=math.ceil(piles[i]/k)hours += math.ceil(piles[i] / k)hours+=math.ceil(piles[i]/k)
    • hours+=(2/4)=1hours += (2 / 4) = 1hours+=(2/4)=1
    • hours+=(4/4)=1hours += (4 / 4) = 1hours+=(4/4)=1
    • hours+=(5/4)=2hours += (5 / 4) = 2hours+=(5/4)=2
    • hours+=(7/4)=2hours += (7 / 4) = 2hours+=(7/4)=2
  • hours<=hhours <= hhours<=h
    • res=4res = 4res=4
      • res=min(res,k)res = min(res, k)res=min(res,k)
    • r=k−1r = k - 1r=k−1

  • k=2k = 2k=2
    • (l+r)//2=2(l + r) // 2 = 2(l+r)//2=2
  • hours=10hours = 10hours=10
    • hours+=math.ceil(piles[i]/k)hours += math.ceil(piles[i] / k)hours+=math.ceil(piles[i]/k)
    • hours+=(2/2)=1hours += (2 / 2) = 1hours+=(2/2)=1
    • hours+=(4/2)=2hours += (4 / 2) = 2hours+=(4/2)=2
    • hours+=(5/2)=3hours += (5 / 2) = 3hours+=(5/2)=3

  • k=3k = 3k=3
    • (l+r)//2=3(l + r) // 2 = 3(l+r)//2=3
  • hours=8hours = 8hours=8
    • hours+=math.ceil(piles[i]/k)hours += math.ceil(piles[i] / k)hours+=math.ceil(piles[i]/k)
    • hours+=(2/3)=1hours += (2 / 3) = 1hours+=(2/3)=1
    • hours+=(4/3)=2hours += (4 / 3) = 2hours+=(4/3)=2
    • hours+=(5/3)=2hours += (5 / 3) = 2hours+=(5/3)=2
    • hours+=(7/3)=3hours += (7 / 3) = 3hours+=(7/3)=3
  • hours<=hhours <= hhours<=h
    • res=3res = 3res=3
      • res=min(res,k)res = min(res, k)res=min(res,k)
    • But notice l==rl == rl==r. No need to continue the algorithm.

Return our result resresres.

Helpful Hints

  • How do I round decimals up?
    • math.ceil(3/2)math.ceil(3/2)math.ceil(3/2)
  • How do I get the max of an array?
    • max(array)max(array)max(array)

Binary Search Solution

class Solution:
    def minEatingSpeed(self, piles: List[int], h: int) -> int:
        # Set our left pointer to 1, lower bound
        l = 1
        # Set our right pointer to max(piles), upper bound
        r = max(piles)
        # Our result in the worse case
        # Is the max amount of bananas
        res = max(piles)

        # l cannot pass r
        while l <= r:
            # Set hours to 0 for each iteration
            hours = 0
            # Set k to the middle pointer
            k = l + ((r - l) // 2)

            # Iterate through the piles
            for i in range(len(piles)):
                # Update our hours
                # Current piles divided by k
                hours += math.ceil(piles[i] / k)
            
            # Check if hours is <= to h
            # Then we can eat k bananas
            if hours <= h:
                # Update result
                res = min(res, k)
                # Check for smaller res
                r = k - 1
            # Else we need to eat more bananas
            else:
                # Check for bigger res
                l = k + 1

        return res
title: Koko Eating Bananas
